Artist: Jerry LaCroix, sound recording by Phonogram, Inc, The grains of paradise]. Faqs.org. Retrieved on August 25, 2013. (born August 25, 1964) is an American actor. He made his debut in the 1985 musical film ''[[Krush Groove]]'' and from 1987 to 1994 starred as attorney Jonathan Rollins in the NBC legal drama series ''[[L.A. Law]]''. Underwood has appeared in a number of films during his career, including ''[[Just Cause (film)|Just Cause]]'' (1995), ''[[Set It Off (film)|Set It Off]]'' (1996), ''[[Deep Impact (film)|Deep Impact]]'' (1998), ''[[Rules of Engagement (film)|Rules of Engagement]]'' (2000), ''[[Something New (film)|Something New]]'' (2006), ''[[Madea's Family Reunion]]'' (2006), and ''[[Juanita (2019 film)|Juanita]]'' (2019). On television, he played a leading role in the 2000 medical drama ''[[City of Angels (2000 TV series)|City of Angels]]'', and the following years had regular roles in ''[[LAX (TV series)|LAX]]'' (2004-05), ''[[Dirty Sexy Money]]'' (2007-09), ''[[In Treatment (U.S. TV series)|In Treatment]]'' (2008), ''[[The Event]]'' (2010-11), ''[[Ironside (2013 TV series)|Ironside]]'' (2013) and ''[[Quantico (TV series)|Quantico]]'' (2016-18). Underwood has received two [[Golden Globe Award]] nominations, five [[NAACP Image Awards]], one [[Daytime Emmy Award]] and one [[Grammy Award]]. ==Early life== Underwood was born in [[Tacoma, Washington]], the son of Marilyn Ann Scales, an [[interior decorator]], and Frank Eugene Underwood, Sr., a [[United States Army]] [[Colonel (United States)|colonel]].[http://www.filmreference.com/film/3/Blair-Underwood.html Blair Underwood Biography (1964–)]. Filmreference.com. Retrieved on August 25, 2013.{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73891646.html?dids=73891646:73891646&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+06%2C+1989&author=Patricia+Brennan&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Blair+Underwood%3B+%60Common+Sense'+Career+Moves&pqatl=google | first=Patricia | last=Brennan | title=Blair Underwood; 'Common Sense' Career Moves | date=August 6, 1989}}Stated on ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (U.S. TV series)|Who Do You Think You Are?]]'', February 24, 2012 Owing to his father's military career, Underwood lived on [[Military base|bases]] and Army Posts in the United States and [[Stuttgart]], Germany during his childhood.{{cite web | title=NPR | work=A Conversation with Blair Underwood | url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1417849 | accessdate=January 7, 2007}} Blair attended [[Petersburg High School (Virginia)|Petersburg High School]] in [[Petersburg, Virginia]].{{citation needed|date=June 2019}} He went on to attend the [[Carnegie Mellon School of Drama]] in [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]], and is an honorary member of the [[Phi Beta Sigma]] fraternity. ==Career== [[File:Blair Underwood at the 41st Emmy Awards cropped.jpg|thumb|right|Underwood at the [[41st Primetime Emmy Awards|41st Emmy Awards]], September 1989]] After his film debut, ''[[Krush Groove]]'', Underwood's 1985 appearance on ''[[The Cosby Show]]'' landed him a short stint for three months on the ABC soap opera ''[[One Life to Live]]'' as Bobby Blue.{{Cite web|url=https://www.soapcentral.com/oltl/news/2017/1213-blair_underwood_erika_slezak.php|title=Blair Underwood thanks OLTL's Erika Slezak for his primetime career|website=soapcentral.com}} He later co-starred in the short-lived CBS crime drama series ''[[Downtown (TV series)|Downtown]]'' from 1986 to 1987, and guest-starred on ''[[Scarecrow and Mrs. King]]'' and ''[[21 Jump Street]]''. In 1987, Underwood, at the age of 21, was cast as attorney Jonathan Rollins in the NBC legal drama series ''[[L.A. Law]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://tvline.com/2017/01/19/blair-underwood-la-law-steven-bochco-prediction-memory/|title=Blair Underwood Recalls L.A. Law EP's Prediction on His First Day on the Job|first1=Kimberly|last1=Roots|first2=Kimberly|last2=Roots|date=January 19, 2017}} He received [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globe Award]] nomination for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Supporting Actor – Series, Miniseries or Television Film|Best Supporting Actor – Series, Miniseries or Television Film]] in 1991. The series ended in 1994. In 1990, he played [[James Chaney]] in the NBC television film ''[[Murder in Mississippi]]''. In 1993, he co-starred in the western film ''[[Posse (1993 film)|Posse]]'' starring [[Mario Van Peebles]]. After ''L.A. Law'', he starred in a number of movies, In 1995 he appeared in the legal thriller ''[[Just Cause (film)|Just Cause]]'', and the following year played [[Jada Pinkett Smith|Jada Pinkett]]' love interest in the heist film ''[[Set It Off (film)|Set It Off]]''. He also had a supporting role as a geneticist in the science fiction film ''[[Gattaca]]'' (1997) and in the disaster film ''[[Deep Impact (film)|Deep Impact]]'' (1998). In 1996 he was featured in the July issue of erotic magazine ''[[Playgirl]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2010/oct/16/one-last-thing-blair-underwood|title=One last thing... Blair Underwood|first=Rich|last=Pelley|date=October 15, 2010|via=www.theguardian.com}} In 1996, Underwood returned to series television with ABC police drama series, ''[[High Incident]]''. He co-starred opposite [[Cicely Tyson]] in the 1998 miniseries ''[[Mama Flora's Family]]''. In 2000, he played the lead role in the short-lived CBS medical drama series ''[[City of Angels (2000 TV series)|City of Angels]]''. Underwood was voted one of ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine's "50 Most Beautiful People" in 2000, and one of ''[[TV Guide]]'' magazine's "Most Influential Faces of the 90s".{{cite web | title=imdb.com | work=Biography for Blair Underwood | url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0005516/bio | accessdate=January 7, 2007}} In 2003, he guest starred in four episodes on the HBO series ''[[Sex and the City]]'' playing [[Cynthia Nixon]]'s love interest. In 2004, he played the role of Roger De Souza opposite [[Heather Locklear]] in NBC short-lived drama ''[[LAX (TV series)|LAX]]''.{{cite web |title=Yahoo Movies |work=Blair Underwood Biography |url=https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800086024/bio |accessdate=January 7, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060516111602/http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800086024/bio |archivedate=May 16, 2006 |df=mdy }} In 2006, he appeared in the [[Tyler Perry]]'s second film, ''[[Madea's Family Reunion]]''. He had a recurring role as the sexy grade school teacher in the CBS sitcom ''[[The New Adventures of Old Christine]]'' opposite [[Julia Louis-Dreyfus]] from 2006 to 2008. In 2007, he guest starred in an episode of the NBC series ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]''.{{cite web |title=MovieWeb |work=NBC's Law & Order: Special Victims Unit January Guest Star Appearances |url=http://www.movieweb.com/tv/news/91/16591.php |accessdate=January 7, 2007 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070109153308/http://www.movieweb.com/tv/news/91/16591.php |archivedate=January 9, 2007 |df=mdy }} In 2007, Underwood portrayed [[Jesus Christ]] in ''[[The Bible Experience|Inspired By… The Bible Experience]],'' an 89-hour, celebrity-voiced, fully dramatized [[audio Bible]] based on [[Today's New International Version]]. Also in 2007, Underwood co-authored the novel ''Casanegra: A Tennyson Hardwick Novel'' with husband-and-wife team [[Steven Barnes]] and [[Tananarive Due]]. [[File:BlairUnderwoodApr09.jpg|thumb|left|Underwood at the premiere for ''[[Earth (2007 film)|Earth]]'' in April 2009]] In 2008, Underwood starred in the first season of the [[HBO]] drama series ''[[In Treatment (U.S. TV series)|In Treatment]]'', for which he was nominated for Best Supporting Actor – Series, Miniseries or Television Film at the [[66th Golden Globe Awards|2009 Golden Globes]].{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Entertainment_News/2008/12/11/TVs_Treatment_up_for_5_Golden_Globes/UPI-34601229009900|title=TV's 'Treatment' up for 5 Golden Globes|publisher=|accessdate=July 9, 2017}} From 2007 to 2009, he was regular cast member in the ABC prime time soap opera, ''[[Dirty Sexy Money]]''. In 2010–2011, Underwood portrayed United States President Elias Martinez in the [[NBC]] drama series ''[[The Event]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2010/05/07/nbc-picks-up-three-new-series-for-2010-11-season-with-the-event-outsourced-and-love-bites/20100507nbc01 |title=NBC Picks Up Three New Series for 2010–11 Season with 'The Event', 'Outsourced' and 'Love Bites'|date=May 7, 2010|work=The Futon Critic|accessdate=May 16, 2010}}{{cite news |url=http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/05/nbc-fall-schedule-2010-11.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100518141626/http://livefeed.hollywoodreporter.com/2010/05/nbc-fall-schedule-2010-11.html |url-status=dead |archive-date=May 18, 2010 |title=NBC's fall schedule, upfront revealed |date=May 16, 2010 |last=Hibberd |first=James |series=The Live Feed |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=May 16, 2010 |df=mdy-all }} In 2010, Underwood portrayed the role of [[Saint Mark]] in ''The Truth & Life Dramatized Audio New Testament Bible'', a 22-hour, celebrity-voiced, fully dramatized audio [[New Testament]], based on the [[RSV-CE]] translation. In 2012, he played the lead role of [[Stanley Kowalski|Stanley]] in the Broadway revival of ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]''.{{cite web|last=Hetrick |first=Adam |title=A Streetcar Named Desire, With Blair Underwood and Nicole Ari Parker, Extends Broadway Run |url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/165961-A-Streetcar-Named-Desire-With-Blair-Underwood-and-Nicole-Ari-Parker-Extends-Broadway-Run |accessdate=26 August 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020031547/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/165961-A-Streetcar-Named-Desire-With-Blair-Underwood-and-Nicole-Ari-Parker-Extends-Broadway-Run |archivedate=October 20, 2013 |df=mdy }} In 2013, Underwood played the role of Robert Ironside in the [[Ironside (2013 TV series)|remake]] of the successful 1960s television series, ''[[Ironside (TV series)|Ironside]]'', made famous by the late [[Raymond Burr]].{{cite news|last=Harnick|first=Chris|title='Ironside': Blair Underwood Says Don't Call It A Remake|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/13/ironside-blair-underwood-remake_n_3268134.html|publisher=The Huffington Post|accessdate=26 August 2013|date=May 13, 2013}} The show was cancelled after three episodes.{{cite news| url=http://insidetv.ew.com/2013/10/03/ironside-nbc-ratings/ }}{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/tv/2013/10/18/community-ironside-nbc-parks-and-recreation/3010581/ | work=USA Today | first1=Gary | last1=Levin | title=NBC yanks 'Ironside,' sets 'Community' return | date=October 18, 2013}} The following year, he appeared in ''[[The Trip to Bountiful (play)|The Trip to Bountiful]]'' opposite [[Cicely Tyson]]. From 2015 to 2016, he had a recurring role in the ABC series ''[[Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.]]''. In 2016, Underwood was cast in the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] thriller series ''[[Quantico (TV series)|Quantico]]'' for the series regular role of [[CIA]] Deputy Director, Owen Hall.{{cite web|url=http://tvline.com/2016/07/05/quantico-blair-underwood-season-2-cast-owen-hall/|title=Quantico: Blair Underwood Joins Season 2 Cast as Series Regular|first1=Michael|last1=Ausiello|first2=Michael|last2=Ausiello|date=July 5, 2016|publisher=|accessdate=July 9, 2017}} The series was canceled after three seasons in 2018. In 2019, Underwood played attorney Bobby Burns in the [[Netflix]] miniseries ''[[When They See Us]]''.{{cite web|url=https://cassiuslife.com/92337/blair-underwood-when-they-see-us-interview/|title=Cassius Chats: Blair Underwood believes there is hope for us yet|last=Grant|first=Andre|work=Cassius Life|date=May 31, 2019|accessdate=June 5, 2019}} The following year, he co-starred opposite [[Octavia Spencer]] in the Netflix miniseries ''[[Self Made (miniseries)|Self Made: Inspired by the Life of Madam C.J. Walker]]''.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bustle.com/p/how-blair-underwoods-self-made-character-cj-walker-differs-from-his-irl-counterpart-22645036|title=The Real Story Of Madam C.J. Walker's Marriage Is So Much Juicier Than In 'Self Made'|website=Bustle}} In January 2020, Underwood appeared on stage as Captain Richard Davenport in the Roundabout Theatre Company's Broadway revival of Charles Fuller’s Pulitzer Prize-winning drama ''[[A Soldier's Play]]''.{{cite web |last1=Stasio |first1=Marilyn |title=‘A Soldier’s Play’: Theater Review |url=https://variety.com/2020/legit/reviews/a-soldiers-play-review-broadway-blair-underwood-1203475543/ |website=Variety |publisher=Variety Media, LLC, a subsidiary of Penske Business Media, LLC. |accessdate=7 February 2020}} ==Personal life== Underwood is a part of several charitable organizations. He won the 1993 Humanitarian Award for his work with the Los Angeles chapter of the [[Muscular Dystrophy Association]]. In 2003, along with [[Ashley Judd]], he served as the spokesperson for [[YouthAIDS]]. In addition, he is involved with the AIDS Healthcare Foundation's Blair Underwood Clinic in Washington, DC.{{cite web|url=http://www.aidshealth.org/archives/news/aids-healthcare-foundations/ |title=AIDS Healthcare Foundation |work=aidshealth.org |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130223121503/http://www.aidshealth.org/archives/news/aids-healthcare-foundations/ |archivedate=February 23, 2013 |df=mdy }} Underwood also appeared in a 2004 [[public service announcement]] for The Fulfillment Fund.{{cite web | title=blairunderwood.com | work=Difference | url=http://www.blairunderwood.com/main.html | accessdate=January 7, 2007 | url-status=dead | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319235656/http://www.blairunderwood.com/main.html | archivedate=March 19, 2006 | df=mdy-all }} He is a Trustee for the [[Robey Theatre Company]] in Los Angeles, a non-profit theatre group founded by [[Danny Glover]], focusing on plays about the [[Black people|Black]] experience. He supported President [[Barack Obama]]'s candidacy and spoke at campaign rallies for Obama. Underwood got to know Obama while researching his ''L.A. Law'' role at [[Harvard Law School]], while Obama was president of the ''[[Harvard Law Review]]''.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/01/28/us/politics/28obama.html?pagewanted=all |title=In Law School, Obama Found Political Voice |accessdate=December 28, 2008 |last=Kantor |first=Jodi |authorlink=Jodi Kantor|date=January 28, 2007|work=The New York Times}} Underwood's [[DNA test]] showed that he is a descendant of the [[Babungo people]] of [[Cameroon]].{{cite web |url=http://www.africanancestry.com/testimonials/index.html |title=Testimonials:A welcome surprise that my people are from Nigeria & Ibo people |first=Blair |last=Underwood |publisher=Africanancestry.com |accessdate=November 23, 2008 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081219183740/http://www.africanancestry.com/testimonials/index.html |archivedate=December 19, 2008 |df=mdy-all }} Additional DNA testing and genealogical research revealed that his African ancestry comes from the [[Bamum people|Bamum]], [[Brong people|Brong]] and [[Igbo people|lgbo]] ethnic groups of Western Africa.[https://web.archive.org/web/20120219011900/http://www.nbc.com/who-do-you-think-you-are/video/preview-blair-underwood/1384511 Preview Blair Underwood]. nbc.com The DNA test also connected Blair to a distant cousin in Babungo, Cameroon.
